moves.4. O-O Bc5 5. Re1: ? While this move does protect White's e pawn, it weakens the f2, which I don't waste time attacking it...
moves.5... Ng4: ...with this move. White has to move the rook again to avoid losing material.
moves.6. Re2 a6: I put a question on White's bishop.
moves.7... dxc6: ...and I capture with my queen's pawn, allowing me to develop my light-squared bishop.
moves.8... h5: !? And I defend it. White cannot take my knight right now. 9.hxg4? hxg4 10.Nxe5 Qh4! with a dangerous mating threat on the h column. This is very similar to the aptly name "Fishing pole" trap.
moves.9. c3: White does not fall for it though.
moves.9... Qd3: !? An Interesting idea; I jam most of White's pieces at the cost of deactivating my trap, as I cannot play Qh4 any longer.
moves.10. b4 Ba7 11. hxg4: White finally captures my knight, but was it safe?
moves.11... hxg4 12. Ne1 Qg3: ! I threaten mate via 13 ...Qh2+ 14.Kf1 Qh1#. The f pawn cannot take my queen as it is pinned by my handy a7 bishop.
moves.13. Re3: The best defence. It blocks the a7-g1 diagonal and frees up the e2 square for the king.
moves.13... Qh2+ 14. Kf1 Bxe3 15. dxe3 Be6: ! A strong move; A bishop on c4 would be very troublesome for white.
moves.16. Nd2: ? This is the losing move. While it does prevent Bc4+ for now, it creates other problems...
moves.16... O-O-O: ...such as this pin on the knight. (Bonus style points for castling to attack?)
moves.17. Qc2: White wisely unpins his knight, but it will not save him.
moves.17... Rxd2: !! I remove the defender of c4 with this sacrifice.
moves.19. Nd3 Rd8: ! I could have played 19... Qh1+ 20.Ke2 Qxa1 here, which would have won as well, but I opted to put more pressure on the knight, squeezing him even more.
moves.20. Ke2 Qxg2: I eye for the f3 square, which would put White's king on the first rank, thus removing a defender of d3.
moves.21. Rd1: 21.Be1 was White's best bet, but it does not stop 21...Qf3+ 22.Kd2 Qxe4, winning the knight.

opening: Ruy Lopez (C65), Berlin defence, Beverwijk variation
